Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2015 01:17AM Alphabet wrote: Original dx-Stage III Grade 3, Jan. 2001 Progression-single bone met (ilium) confirmed with biopsy Feb. 3, 2011. Faslodex 4+ years. Zometa 3 years-stopped until future progression.
Posts.Title: How long have you been Stage IV? goldie0827 dormouse

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 08:05PM Alphabet wrote: For several years (prior to Stage IV diagnosis) I had double vision when I was overtired. This past fall I went over the visual cliff and was seeing double all of the time, although my near vision was okay. (Near vision=up to 5 feet). I was going to go back to my optometrist and get prism glasses as we had discussed when this first came up. In December I mentioned the problem to my medical oncologist. Wow-brain MRI within four days and a referral to a neuro-ophthomologist. I now have a temporary prism that has been wonderful. The neuro requested an up to date PET scan and a lumbar puncture. The MRI, PET and LP are all negative thankfully. I return to him next week and hopefully he will agree that the double vision is not caused by cancer.
Posts.Title: Blurry vision Wilsie2 Alphabet

Posts.Content: Alphabet wrote: I know that my mother, "Alphabet", didn't post very much but she read here for hours every day soaking in your stories and knowledge. She passed on Friday after a battle with pneumonitis and ARDS brought on by Afinator. As her daughter I am grateful for your support and knowledge provided to my mom. Keep fighting the fight ladies!!! You are all in my thoughts and prayers. Karen bone mets (thoracic and lumbar spine, rib) Hormonal Therapy 4/14/2011 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My mom has passed Alphabet RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 04:32PM Alphabet wrote: Hi Maryannel-Central Jersey is cold! This winter cold has been rough for all, but an added burden for many of the Sandy victims. I was so fortunate to not lose power or have damage to my property. I was running a place for friends to have showers and hot dinners. I'll let you know how things go with my return visit to the neuro-ophthamologist next week. Hopefully no more tests, but onc said that the LP was only about 90% accurate and that ophth might want another one or two. No fun.
Posts.Title: Blurry vision Wilsie2 Alphabet

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 04:30PM Alphabet wrote: Neuro-ophthamologist pleased with test results. It is definitely Sixth Nerve Palsy, a neurological problem, but we may never find the cause since it apparently is independent of my Stage IV diagnosis. It may go away or improve or it may stay the same. (If it gets worse I will be back to testing.)The prism has made me "normal" again and I could be very happy with this solution long term if things don't improve. The time frame for improvement is about 6 months and I'm still within that period. Good appointment with MO earlier this week-Zometa and Faslodex too. Now to hear about the TMs which have been holding in the low 60s. They have been indicative for me.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2014 12:29PM Alphabet wrote: With only one bone met identified, I had Zometa monthly the first year, every other month the second year, and every third month the third year. Doctor stopped the infusions with the option to restart if/when I have new bone mets. I know another woman who has been on monthly Zometa continually for over a decade, but I think that is very unusual.
Posts.Title: How long did you stay on Zometa? Kandy teacher911

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2012 12:20PM Alphabet wrote: I too had adriamycin and cytoxan together nearly 12 years ago. I was given an Rx for Zofran to start the night before infusions. To this day, I say "Zofran is my friend" though 7 pills for each treatment cost $163 after insurance. I worked throughout my neoadjuvant treatment and never fell out of low normal on WBC or RBC. Hair started coming out on day 13. During the infusion I was given a popsicle to lick to hopefully (and successfully) prevent any mouth sores. Again, drink water, drink water, drink water!
